_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

PERDUE FARMS, INCORPORATED

MILFORD, DELAWARE

2014



Facility Description and Regulated Substances

Perdue Foods LLC, founded in 1920, is the largest poultry producer in the Northeast and the third largest in the United States. Headquartered in Salisbury, Maryland, the family-owned, privately held company has operations in 15 states. Fifteen processing facilities produce about 56 million pounds of poultry products each week. Perdue also has grain storage and merchandising operations and is ranked among the top 12 largest US grain companies. In addition, Perdue manufactures edible oils, specialty feeds, livestock feed ingredients and premium pet food ingredients.



The Perdue Farms Milford Food Plant (P-1318) is located at 255 North Rehoboth Boulevard, Milford, Delaware. This facility processes whole birds and other valued-added poultry products. Perdue Foods LLC purchased this facility and started operations in October 1995. The facility is sited on about 27 acres, on the north side of town, east of Route 113. It is bounded by some residences, industries and farmland.



Anhydrous ammonia is onsite and is regulated under CFR Part 68. It is used for refrigeration. The Perdue Milford facility has one system containing 48,613 pounds of ammonia. It is distributed throughout the components (compressors, condensers, evaporators, etc.). The system has equipment both inside and outside of the facility.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

As a concerned member of the communities in which Perdue facilities are located, the company takes its role as a responsible corporate citizen very seriously. All Perdue facilities are operated to protect employees, contractors and the public from injury and illness, and to minimize environmental impact. A company-wide safety and wellness program stresses  safe  working  conditions and safe practices. Perdue's policy is to inspect, maintain and operate equipment and facilities to prevent a

ccidents, including release of hazardous materials; and to train employees in prevention, as well as to prepare them to respond rapidly and effectively should an accident occur.



Perdue Foods LLC has developed and implemented Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) and Process Safety Management (PSM) plans  at each regulated facility as part of an overall chemical management program. The program involves a wide-range of senior management personnel, including the Vice President of Environmental Services and the Director of Safety and Security. Additionally, Perdue conducts regular safety meetings and provides a wide variety of environmental, health and safety training to its staff.



Accident Release Prevention Program

Perdue Milford has complied with Delaware's Extremely Hazardous Substance Risk Management Act (EHSRMA) since its promulgation in 1989 and the OSHA Process Safety Management regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 of 1992. Up-to-date process information, such as equipment information, piping and instrument diagrams and Material Safety Data Sheets, are kept onsite. Employee participation includes operation and maintenance procedures development, review and training. Contractors are required to submit qualification statements of competency. Process hazard analyses with recommendations have been done, and corrective actions taken. Annual mechanical integrity inspections are scheduled. In addition, Perdue performs internal audits on its PSM substances.



Five-Year Accident History

There have been no on-site accidents involving ammonia at the Perdue Milford facility that have resulted in death, injuries, property damage or environmental damage.



Emergency Response Program

Perdue Milford has implemented a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan in accordance with the OSHA PSM regulations. The facility has a trained HAZWOPER (HAZardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response) team that will respond in the event of a hazardous material release or other em

ergency situation. The Plan contains specific information regarding emergency response organization and procedures, as well as incident notification, mitigation and incident preparedness. Evacuation exercises are conducted, and drills are scheduled with the local emergency responders, Carlisle Fire Company.



Perdue Milford is a member of the Kent County Local Emergency Planning Committee and is part of the community emergency response plan. The State of Delaware and DEMA (Delaware Emergency Management Agency)  have instituted the First Alert Telephone Notification System that allows for a "reverse 911" procedure for notification of communities in the event of a chemical release or other emergency. The system can be activated by the Fire Company Incident Commander, Manager of Kent LEPC or the SERT (State Emergency Response Team).



Planned Changes  to Improve Safety

There are two RETA (Refrigeration Engineering Technician Association) Level A Certified    operators at the facility. Perdue  continues its  five-year PRV replacement program. In April 2009 a new rechiller was installed. We have replaced new oil pots on all four recirculators. Have improved the relief valve discharge pipes. A new ammonia detection system was installed that expanded the protection area. In 2008 a new hazwoper trailer was bought and supplied with new response equipment. In 2013 we have made changes to the plant. With these additions we added new condenser, new evaporators, and other processing equipment that uses ammonia in the process.



As part of Perdue Farms' continual improvement philosophy, the Perdue Milford facility continues to identify and update system components and techniques to ensure safety and quality.



Revised January 18, 2014
